column2: Slovakia officially adopts the Euro currency and becomes the sixteenth Eurozone country.
61 die in nightclub fire in Bangkok, Thailand.
The government of the Republic of China adopts Hanyu Pinyin as its official Chinese romanization (before this time, the most commonly used was Tongyong Pinyin.
95th Rose Bowl: #5 Southern California beats #6 Penn State, 38-24
75th Orange Bowl: #21 Virginia Tech beats #12 Cincinnati, 20-7
75th Sugar Bowl: #6 Utah beats #4 Alabama, 31-17
Israeli ground forces invade Gaza.
The Bitcoin network is created as the first block of the digital currency is mined by a person or group of people using the name Satoshi Nakamoto

Phil Taylor, with a 7–1 victory in the final over Dutchman Raymond van Barneveld wins his 12th PDC World Darts title, his 14th in all; his 110.94 average remains a record for the PDC World Darts Championship final
38th Fiesta Bowl: #3 Texas beats #10 Ohio State, 24-21
Israel begins an assault on the Gaza Strip
Dakota Fanning receives the Rising Star Award at the 20th Annual Palm Springs International Film Festival
35th People's Choice Awards: Will Smith & Reese Witherspoon win (Movie Star) and Hugh Laurie & Christina Applegate win (TV)
A 6.2 magnitude earthquake hit Costa Rica´s region of Volcan Poás, with an epicenter near Cinchona. It was caused by Varablanca-Angel fault.
14th Critics' Choice Movie Awards: Slumdog Millionaire wins Best Film
College Football, 11th BCS National Championship, Dolphin Stadium, Miami Gardens: #2 Florida beats #1 Oklahoma, 24-14
Hopman Cup Tennis, Perth: Dominik Hrbatý beats Russia's Marat Safin 6-7, 7-5, 7-6 for an unassailable 2-0 lead, and Slovakia's 3rd title
66th Golden Globes: Slumdog Millionaire, Mickey Rourke, Kate Winslet win
Cristiano Ronaldo is awarded 2008 FIFA World Player of the Year for the first time at a ceremony in Zurich
Global shipping experiences a drop in trade, as exports from South Korea dropping an annualised 30%, with Taiwan and Japan experiencing a 42% and 27% drop respectively

Chesley Sullenberger lands US Airways Flight 1549 on the Hudson River shortly after takeoff from LaGuardia Airport in NYC. All passengers and crew members survive in what becomes known as the "Miracle on the Hudson"
AFC Championship, Heinz Field, Pittsburgh: Pittsburgh Steelers beat Baltimore Ravens, 23-14
NFC Championship, University of Phoenix Stadium: Arizona Cardinals beat Philadelphia Eagles, 32-25
Barack Obama, inaugurated as the 44th President of the United States of America, becomes the United States' first African-American president
Joe Biden assumes the office of the Vice President of the United States
Dendermonde nursery attack occurred in Dendermonde, Belgium.
UK officially enters recession as GDP falls by 1.5% in the last quarter of 2008 following a 0.6% drop in the third quarter, with unemployment growing by 131,000 to 1.92 million (6.1%)
Pope Benedict XVI rescinds the excommunications of four bishops consecrated without papal consent in 1988 by Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre.
57th NHL All-Star Game, Bell Centre, Montreal, Quebec: East beats West, 12-11, SO; MVP: Alexei Kovalev, Montreal Canadiens, RW
25th Sundance Film Festival: "Precious" based on the Novel "Push" by Sapphire" wins Grand Jury Prize Dramatic
"Blame It (On the Alcohol)" single released by Jamie Foxx featuring T-Pain (Billboard Song of the Year 2009)
"I Run to You" single by Lady Antebellum is released (Grammy Award Best Country Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal 2009, Billboard Song of the Year 2009)
Rod Blagojevich, the Governor of Illinois, is removed from office after being convicted of corruption charges
In Kenya, at least 113 people are killed and over 200 injured following an oil spillage ignition in Molo, days after a massive fire at a Nakumatt supermarket in Nairobi killed at least 25 people.
Australian Open Women's Tennis: Serena Williams wins 10th Grand Slam singles title; outclasses Dinara Safina of Russia 6-0, 6-3
Jóhanna Sigurðardóttir is elected as the first female Prime Minister of Iceland, becoming the first openly gay Head of Government in the modern world.
Super Bowl XLIII, Raymond James Stadium, Tampa, FL: Pittsburgh Steelers beat Arizona Cardinals, 27-23; MVP: Santonio Holmes, Pittsburgh, WR
Australian Open Men's Tennis: Spanish ace Rafael Nadal wins his first Australian title; beats Roger Federer 7-5, 3-6, 7-6, 3-6, 6-2
"RuPaul's Drag Race" hosted by RuPaul premieres on Logo TV
Eric Holder becomes 82nd and 1st African American US Attoney General, succeeding Michael Mukasey
The United States Navy guided missile cruiser Port Royal runs aground off Oahu, Hawaii, damaging the ship as well as a coral reef
59th Berlin International Film Festival: "The Milk of Sorrow" wins the Golden Bear
Bushfires in Victoria left 173 dead in the worst natural disaster in Australia's history.
51st Grammy Awards: Best Album "Raising Sand" and Record of the Year "Please Read The Letter" by Robert Plant & Alison Krauss
NFL Pro Bowl, Aloha Stadium, Honolulu, HI: NFC beats AFC, 30-21; MVP: Larry Fitzgerald, Arizona Cardinals, WR
62nd British Film and Television Awards (BAFTAS): "Slumdog Millionaire" Best Film, Danny Boyle Best Director
Singer Rihanna cancels appearance at the Grammys after being assaulted by boyfriend Chris Brown
Uri Geller purchases Lamb Island, Scotland, previously known for its witch trials
Colgan Air Flight 3407 crashes near Buffalo in the state of New York killing 50 people.
40th NAACP Image Awards: "The Secret Life of Bees" wins Outstanding Motion Picture
Unix time passed 1,234,567,890 seconds February 13, 2009 at exactly 23:31:30 (UTC).
The Dutch Statistics agency confirms the Netherlands are in recession
58th NBA All-Star Game, US Airways Center, Phoenix, AZ: West beats East, 146-119; MVPs: Kobe Bryant, LA Lakers, F; Shaquille O'Neal, LA Lakers, C
51st Daytona 500: Matt Kenseth wins shortened race; called off with 48 laps to go after a severe rainstorm hits the track

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics announced that the Taiwanese economy has contracted an unprecedented 8.36% in the fourth quarter of 2008; thus placing the country in a technical recession
English fantasy author Terry Pratchett receives a knighthood from Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace
29th Golden Raspberry Awards: "The Love Guru" wins
81st Academy Awards: "Slumdog Millionaire", Sean Penn & Kate Winslet win
Heath Ledger posthumously wins Academy Award, Best Supporting Actor, for his performance as the Joker in "The Dark Knight"
BDR massacre in Pilkhana, Dhaka, Bangladesh. 74 People are being killed, including more than 50 Army officials, by Bangladeshi Boarder Guards inside its headquarter.
Statistics Finland informs that Finland's gross domestic product diminished by 1.3% in the last quarter of 2008 from the previous quarter
Steven Holcomb pilots USA-1 sled to victory in the 4-man competition at the World Bobsled Championships at Mt Van Hoevenberg, NY; first American win in the event in 50 years
The Sri Lankan cricket team is attacked by terrorists while on their way to the Gaddafi Stadium, Lahore for 2nd Test against Pakistan; match abandoned
The building of the Historisches Archiv der Stadt Köln (Historical Archives) in Cologne, Germany, collapses.

International Criminal Court issues an arrest warrant for Sudanese President Omar Hassan al-Bashir for war crimes and crimes against humanity in Darfur becoming the first sitting head of state to be indicted
U.S. Steel announce the closure of the Stelco Lake Erie Works in Nanticoke, Ontario due to the increasingly worsening effects of the global economic slowdown

Malaysia has a 50% chance of slipping into the recession as growth is expected to reach just 0.5% for the year, announces the executive director Datuk Mohamed Ariff Abdul Kareem of the Malaysian Institute of Economic Research
Moises Alou announces he will retire following the World Baseball Classic
Despite only being 17 years old, Brazilian soccer star Neymar makes his professional debut for Santos
Billy Corgan testifies in front of Congress, on behalf of the musicFIRST Coalition, in support of H.R. 848, the Performance Rights Act
Winnenden school shooting - 17 people are killed at a school in Germany.
30th Big East Men's Basketball Tournament: #5 Louisville beats #10 Villanova, 69-55

Canterbury winger Hazem El Masri becomes highest point scorer in Australian Rugby League history; 33rd minute penalty in Bulldogs' 34-12 win over Manly at ANZ Stadium, Sydney takes him to 2,178; Andrew Johns, 2,176
56th ACC Men's Basketball Tournament: #9 Duke beats #22 Florida State, 79-69
50th SEC Men's Basketball Tournament: Mississippi State beats Tennessee, 64-61
Ireland completes a Grand Slam with a 17-15 win over Wales at Millennium Stadium, Cardiff to win the Six Nations Rugby Championship
Mount Redoubt, a volcano in Alaska began erupting after a prolonged period of unrest
Cricket Women's World Cup: England defeats New Zealand by 4 wickets
Gay dating site Grindr launched by Joel Simkhai, first ever dating application to combine dating information and location
Situ Gintung, an artificial lake in Indonesia, fails killing at least 99 people.
The first cases of H1N1 swine flu in the United States occur in two people in California
"Boom Boom Pow" single released by The Black Eyed Peas (Grammy Award for Best Music Video 2010, Billboard Song of the Year 2009)
Croatia and Albania join NATO
Australia formally adopts the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples
162nd Grand National: French-bred 100/1 outsider Mon Mome, ridden by Liam Treadwell, wins by 12 lengths from defending champion Comply or Die
Eminem Inducts Run-DMC Into Rock And Roll Hall Of Fame

North Korea launches its controversial Kwangmyŏngsŏng-2 rocket. The satellite passed over mainland Japan, which prompted an immediate reaction from the United Nations Security Council, as well as participating states of Six-party talks
44th Academy of Country Music Awards: Carrie Underwood & Brad Paisley win
Kraft Nabisco Championship Women's Golf, Mission Hills CC: Brittany Lincicome eagles the final hole to win her first major title, 1 stroke ahead of fellow American Cristie Kerr
WrestleMania XXV, Reliant Stadium, Houston, TX (72,744): The Undertaker defeats Shawn Michaels; John Cena beats Edge and The Big Show; Triple H downs Randy Orton
A 6.3 magnitude earthquake strikes near L'Aquila, Italy, killing at least 253.
71st NCAA Men's Basketball Championship: North Carolina beats Michigan State, 89-72; Tar Heels' 5th national title; Ty Lawson 21 points
"Star Trek" film reboot directed by J.J. Abrams, starring Chris Pine and Zachary Quinto premieres in Austin, Texas
Former Peruvian President Alberto Fujimori is sentenced to 25 years in prison for ordering killings and kidnappings by security forces
28th NCAA Women's Basketball Championship: Connecticut beats Louisville, 76-54; Huskies' 6th national title with center Tina Charles MOP
Mockumentary "Parks and Recreation" starring Amy Poehler, Nick Offerman and Aziz Ansari debuts on NBC in the US
U.S. Navy rescues captain Richard Phillips, killing three pirates and capturing a fourth
President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian National Authority makes a courtesy phone call to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, restarting the Palestinian-Israeli dialogue

73rd US Masters Tournament, Augusta National GC: Ángel Cabrera wins his 2nd major title in a playoff with Chad Campbell and Kenny Perry; Cabrera, first Masters champion from Argentina and South America

Even though official government sources state that Argentina's GDP will actually grow this year, private consulting firms state that Argentine economy has actually been in recession since October 2008
Laureus World Sports Awards, (ceremony cancelled GFC): Sportsman: Usain Bolt; Sportswoman: Yelena Isinbayeva; Team: China Olympic team
Former New Zealand Prime Minister Helen Clark becomes the Administrator of the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), the first woman to lead the organization
113th Boston Marathon: Deriba Merga of Ethiopia wins men's event in 2:08:42; Salina Kosgei of Kenya women's champion in 2:32:16
Gamma ray burst (GRB) 090423 is observed for 10 seconds, the most distant object of any kind and also the oldest known object in the universe
Elijah Wood is honored with the Midnight Award by the San Francisco International Film Festival
NFL Draft: Georgia quarterback Matthew Stafford first pick by Detroit Lions
55th British Academy Television Awards: "Harry and Paul" Best Comedy, "Wallander" Best Drama
Chrysler automobile company files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy
Failed attack on the Dutch Royal Family results in 7 deaths and 17 injured
The United Kingdom formally ends combat operations in Iraq
Same-sex marriage is legalized in Sweden
Carol Ann Duffy is appointed British Poet Laureate - first Scot and woman Laureate
Chanda Kochhar takes over from K. V. Kamath as CEO and Managing Director of ICICI Bank
135th Kentucky Derby: Calvin Borel wins aboard 50-1 long shot Mine That Bird
Jacob Zuma is sworn in as President of South Africa
PGA Players Championship, TPC at Sawgrass: Henrik Stenson of Sweden shoots a bogey-free final round 66 to win by 4 strokes from Englishman Ian Poulter
An American soldier in Iraq opened fire on a counseling center at Camp Liberty in Bagdhad, leaving 5 other US soldiers dead and 3 soldiers wounded

French Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies announce French narrowly avoided recession in 2008, gross domestic product shrank 1.2% in 1st quarter of 2009 after falling by 1.5% in final quarter of 2008
Eurostat report that Austria, Belgium, and Romania have all entered recession in the first quarter of 2009
"Farrah's Story" documentary following Farrah Fawcett's battle with cancer airs on NBC in the US
India's General Election results announced: the United Progressive Alliance (UPA) under Manmohan Singh returned with an increased mandate
134th Preakness: Calvin Borel aboard Rachel Alexandra wins in 1:55.08
54th Eurovision Song Contest: Alexander Rybak for Norway wins singing "Fairytale" in Moscow
Video game Minecraft is first released to the public while in development
Sri Lankan Civil War: The LTTE are defeated by the Sri Lankan government, ending almost 26 years of fighting between the two sides.
Sri Lanka announces victory in its 25-year war against the terrorist organisation, Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam
Mexico is the first Latin American country to officially enter recession
Indianapolis 500: Hélio Castroneves wins in 3:19:34.6427 (241.913 km/h)
62nd Cannes Film Festival: "The White Ribbon" directed by Michael Haneke wins the Palme d'Or
Manchester United wins 1-0 at Hull City Stadium to win English Premier League title for 3rd consecutive season, for a second time; equals Liverpool's record of 18 league titles
IPL Cricket Final, New Wanderers Stadium, Johannesburg, RSA: Deccan Chargers beat Royal Challengers Bangalore by 6 runs; Herschelle Gibbs top scores, 53 (48)
Senior PGA Championship Men’s Golf, Canterbury GC: Michael Allen wins his lone major title by 2 strokes from runner-up Larry Mize
North Korea conducts its second nuclear test while also conducting several missile tests
Thailand’s economy shrank more than expected in the first quarter of 2009, contracting the most in a decade and plunging the nation into recession
NHL Eastern Conference Final: Pittsburgh Penguins beat Carolina Hurricanes, 4 games to 0
South Africa enters the global recession; the first recession for South Africa in 17 years
NHL Western Conference Final: Detroit Red Wings beat Chicago Black Hawks, 4 games to 1
UEFA Champions League Final, Rome: Barcelona beats Manchester United, 2-0; first Spanish treble of La Liga, Copa del Rey and Champions League
Super Rugby Final, Pretoria: Morné Steyn kicks 5 conversions & 2 penalties as the Bulls thump the Chiefs (Waikato, NZ), 61-17
English FA Cup Final, Wembley Stadium, London (89,391): Chelsea beats Everton, 2-1; Frank Lampard scores 72' winner
Air France Flight 447 crashes into the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Brazil on a flight from Rio de Janeiro to Paris. All 228 passengers and crew were killed.
General Motors files for chapter 11 bankruptcy. It is the fourth largest United States bankruptcy in history.
Switzerland officially enters the global recession
Chile officially enters recession; it is the first South American country to enter the global recession
At least 32 people are killed in Peru during clashes between the police and indigenous protesters
141st Belmont: Kent Desormeaux aboard Summer Bird wins in 2:27.54
French Open Women's Tennis: Svetlana Kuznetsova beats fellow Russian and World #1 Dinara Safina 6-4, 6-2
63rd Tony Awards: "Billy Elliot the Musical" and "God of Carnage" win
French Open Men's Tennis: Roger Federer wins his only French title, outclassing Robin Söderling of Sweden 6-1, 7-6, 6-4
Brazil officially enters recession

Texas mother hit by lightning while standing in her kitchen in her Texas home. Witnesses say lightning came through a light fixture, struck her chest and exited her foot. Survived after three days in hospital.
Bulgarian authorities declare the country is officially in recession after dropping 1.6% in the last quarter of 2008
The World Health Organization declares H1N1 swine flu to be a global pandemic, the first such incident in over forty years
Protests in Iran following the presidential election.
TSC: All television broadcasts in the United States switch from analog NTSC to digital ATSC transmission.
Stanley Cup Final, Joe Louis Arena, Detroit, MI: Pittsburgh Penguins edge Detroit Red Wings, 2-1 for a 4-3 series win; Penguins 3rd Championship
NBA Finals: Los Angeles Lakers beat Orlando Magic, 99-86 in Game 5 for franchise's 15th NBA championship; MVP: Kobe Bryant
LPGA Championship Women's Golf, Bulle Rock GC: 22 year old Tour rookie Anna Nordqvist of Sweden wins her only major title by 4 strokes ahead of runner-up Lindsey Wright
43rd CMT Music Awards: Taylor Swift & Brad Paisley wins
"Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen" directed by Michael Bay and starring Shia LaBeouf and Megan Fox is released
ICC Women's Cricket T20 World Cup, Lord's: England 86/4 win inaugural event; beat New Zealand 85; England's Katherine Brunt takes 3 for 6
Two Metro subway trains collide in Washington, D.C., killing 9 and injuring over 80
US Open Men's Golf, Bethpage State Park: Lucas Glover wins his only major title, 2 strokes ahead of runners-up Ricky Barnes, David Duval and Phil Mickelson
Akio Toyoda is confirmed as the new President of the Toyota Motor Corporation
Mike Babcock is named head coach of Team Canada for the 2010 Winter Olympics (they would win the gold medal)
Colombia enters into recession after witnessing 0.7% contraction in the last quarter of 2008 and 0.6% in the following quarter
NBA Draft: Oklahoma power forward Blake Griffin first pick by Los Angeles Clippers
Fayette Pinkney, American pop-soul singer (The Three Degrees - "When Will I See You Again?") dies of acute respiratory failure at 61
Professor Stephen Hawking hosts a 'party for time travellers' at the University of Cambridge, not sending out the invites until after the party
Financier Bernard Madoff sentenced to 150 years in prison, US maximum, for conducting massive Ponzi scheme
Yemenia Flight 626 crashes off the coast of Moroni, Comoros killing 152 people and leaving 1 survivor
Turkey records its fastest contraction of 13.8% in the first quarter of 2009 compared to 2008, leading the country into recession; this is Turkey's biggest economic slump since 1945
Animated film "Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs" directed by Carlos Saldanha and Mike Thurmeieris with voices by Ray Romano and John Leguizamo is released
Mark II.5 Skytrain cars enter service in Metro Vancouver.
Wimbledon Women's Tennis: Serena Williams beats older sister Venus 7-6, 6-2 for her 3rd Wimbledon singles title
Ethnic rioting breaks out in Ürümqi, Xinjiang, People's Republic of China
Wimbledon Men's Tennis: Roger Federer beats Andy Roddick of the US 5-7, 7-6, 7-6, 3-6, 16-14 for a record 15th Grand Slam singles title
Jadranka Kosor became first female prime minister of Croatia
Joe Sakic retires after 21 NHL seasons with the Quebec Nordiques/Colorado Avalanche franchise, finishing with 625 goals and 1,641 points
US Open Women's Golf, Saucon Valley CC: Eun-Hee Ji of South Korea wins her lone major title, 1 stroke ahead of American runner-up Candie Kung
"She Wolf", the lead single from Shakira's eighth album, premieres
80th All Star Baseball Game: AL wins 4-3 at Busch Stadium, St Louis

Singapore experiences a seasonally adjusted and annualised growth of 20.4% in the second quarter as a result of increased pharmaceuticals production and construction, bringing the country out of the recession
A 7.9 Magnitude earthquake registers 160km west of Invercargill, New Zealand, creating a small tsunami
"Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince", the 6th film based on the books by J. K. Rowling is released worldwide
Jakarta double bombings at the JW Marriott and Ritz-Carlton Hotels killed 9 people including 4 foreigners
Five members of one family are found murdered at Epping, New South Wales.
British Open Men's Golf, Turnberry: American Stewart Cink wins his only major championship by 6 strokes in a 4-hole playoff with 5-time champion Tom Watson
The Wesley Impact: black spot the size of Earth discovered on Jupiter after unknown object crashed onto the planet
17th ESPY Awards: Michael Phelps, Nastia Liukin wins
Mark Buehrle of the Chicago White Sox becomes the 18th pitcher to throw a perfect game in MLB history, defeating Tampa Bay Rays 5-0
The Bank of Canada announces the end of the recession even though it remains nascent and still dependent on government stimulus money
42nd San Diego Comic-Con International opens at San Diego Convention Center

FINA Congress votes to ban all body-length swimsuits; men's suits to maximally cover from the waist to knee, and women's from shoulder to knee; fabric must be a "textile" or woven material; effective 1 January 2010
96th Tour de France won by Alberto Contador of Spain
British Senior Open Men's Golf, Sunningdale: American Loren Roberts wins his second Open Senior title in a playoff with Mark McNulty and Fred Funk
Temperature reaches 103°F in Seattle, Washington, the hottest day on record [1]
A bomb explodes in Palma Nova, Mallorca, killing 2 police officers. Basque separatist group ETA is believed to be responsible.
Michael Phelps ends the World Swimming Championships in Rome with his 5th gold medal as part of the US 4x100m medley relay team that recorded the 43rd world record of the controversial meet
US Open Senior Men's Golf, Crooked Stick GC: Fred Funk wins by 6 strokes from Joey Sindelar with a tournament record score (-20)
British Open Women's Golf, Royal Lytham & St Annes GC: Catriona Matthew wins her lone major title, 3 strokes ahead of runner-up Karrie Webb; first Scot to win the title
Kim Jong-il meets former president Bill Clinton. He pardons and releases captured American journalists Euna Lee and Laura Ling who were found guilty of entering the country illegally.
“Tik Tok” single released by Kesha (Billboard Song of the Year 2010)
"Need You Now" album released by Lady Antebellum (Billboard Album of the Year 2010)
Portugal leaves recession after three consecutive quarters of negative growth having its GDP recover by 0.3% in the second quarter of 2009
12th Athletics World Championships open at Berlin, Germany
PGA Championship Men's Golf, Hazeltine National GC: Yang Yong-eun of South Korea wins his first major title by 3 strokes from Tiger Woods
Usain Bolt of Jamaica edges American Tyson Gay to win 100m in world record 9.58s at the World Athletics Championships in Berlin
A series of bombings in Baghdad, Iraq, kills 101 and injures 565 others
12th Athletics World Championships: Usain Bolt wins 200m
Solheim Cup Women's Golf, Rich Harvest Farms: US wins 3rd consecutive Cup 16-12; win 8 of 12 singles to dominate final day
The Tradition Senior Men's Golf, Crosswater Club: Mike Reid wins his second Champions Tour major with birdie on first playoff hole against John Cook
Thailand's GDP grew 2.3% in 2009's second quarter, technically leaving the recession
"Love Like Crazy" single released by Lee Brice (Billboard Song of the Year 2010)
Cristiano Ronaldo makes his debut for Real Madrid, scoring a penalty in their 3-2 win over Deportivo La Coruña
66th Venice Film Festival: "Lebanon" directed by Samuel Maoz wins Golden Lion
Denmark celebrates the first national flagday, in memory of the fallen Danes in international operations since 1948.
Canadian Open Women's Golf, Priddis Greens GC: Suzann Pettersen of Norway wins by 5 strokes from a group of 5 players
Cyprus enters recession after 0.6% contraction in the first quarter, followed by 0.4% in the second quarter
The Brazilian economy technically leaves the recession when GDP grew 1.9% in the second quarter of 2009 after having fallen in the first quarter of 2009 and last quarter of 2008
Sweden emerges from the recession after witnessing GDP growth of 0.2% in the second quarter
The 9-12 Project organized multiple marches and demonstrations across the USA to protest government spending.
US Open Women's Tennis: Belgian Kim Clijsters becomes first unseeded player and wildcard to win the tournament; beats Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark 7-5, 6-3

South Africa claims 3rd Tri Nations Rugby Series with 32-29 win over defending champions New Zealand in Hamilton; Steyn bros dominate with the boot; Morné kicks 2 penalties, 2 conversions & dropped goal; François, 3 penalties
26th MTV Video Music Awards: Beyoncé, Taylor Swift & T.I. f/ Rihanna win
David Attenborough and Prince William officially open the Darwin Centre at the National History Museum London, in what is the Museum's most significant expansion since 1881
US Open Men's Tennis: Juan Martín del Potro of Argentina wins his first Grand Slam title; beats defending champion Roger Federer 3-6, 7-6, 4-6, 7-6, 6-2
The 72 year run of the soap opera The Guiding Light ends as its final episode is broadcast.
34th Toronto International Film Festival: "Precious" directed by Lee Daniels wins the People's Choice Award
61st Emmy Awards: Mad Men, 30 Rock, Bryan Cranston & Glenn Close win
Macedonia officially enters the recession after experiencing a drop in GDP of 0.9% in the first quarter, followed by 1.4% in the second quarter
Crime drama "NCIS LA" starring Chris O'Donnell, LL Cool J and Daniela Ruah premieres on CBS
"Modern Family" premieres on ABC, starring Ed 'Neill and Sofia Vergara
Typhoon Ketsana (2009) hit the Philippines, China, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos and Thailand, causing 700 fatalities.
German Federal elections return Angela Merkel for her second term as Chancellor at head of centre-right coalition government
The military junta leading Guinea, headed by Captain Moussa Dadis Camara, sexually assaulted, killed and wounded protesters during a protest rally in a stadium called Stade du 28 Septembre.
An 8.0 magnitude earthquake near the Samoan Islands causes a tsunami.
MESSENGER spacecraft performs a third and final Mercury flyby
The International Olympic Committee votes to award Rio de Janeiro, Brazil rights to host the 2016 Summer Olympics and Paralympics
The economic crisis in Ireland is considered to be the driving force behind the largest migration of Irish people to London in 20 years, it is reported today
"Stan Lee Day" declared by County of Los Angeles and the City of Long Beach
George Papandreou's Panhellenic Socialist Movement defeats Greece's governing New Democracy party in an electoral landslide.
Senior Players Championship Men's Golf, Baltimore CC: Jay Haas wins his third and final Champions Tour major title by 1 stroke from Tom Watson
Australia wins cricket's Champions Trophy at Centurion Park in Gauteng, South Africa by 6 wickets (28 balls remaining) v New Zealand; chasing 200, Shane Watson is 105 not out in Australia's 206/4

A digital version of psychiatrist Carl Gustav Jung's 'Red Book' is published 48 years after his death and contains personal notes on his subconscious during the period in which he developed his principal theories
First lunar impact of the Centaur and LCROSS spacecrafts as part of NASA's Lunar Precursor Robotic Program
After closed borders for nearly two hundred years, Armenia and Turkey sign protocols in Zurich to open their borders
Presidents Cup Golf, Harding Park GC: US down International team, 19½–14½; their 2nd consecutive win by that score and 3rd straight overall
QB Tom Brady throws five second quarter touchdowns against the Tennessee Titans, an NFL record for touchdown passes in one quarter
British Mercedes driver Jenson Button finishes 5th in Brazilian Grand Prix at Autódromo José Carlos Pace to clinch his first F1 World Drivers Championship
MLB National League Championship: Philadelphia Phillies beat Los Angeles Dodgers, 4 games to 1
55th National Film Awards (India): "Kanchivaram" wins the Golden Lotus
Microsoft releases Windows 7
The United Nations "Rotterdam Rules" convention regulating international maritime carriage of goods is ratified with its twentieth signature.
The UK markets had contracted by 0.4% in the third quarter against what was expected to be a period of growth, as a result of unexpectedly poor performance by the service sector
First International Day of Climate Action, organized with 350.org, a global campaign to address a claimed global warming crisis.
19th College Football Holy War: Notre Dame beats Boston College 20-16 in South Bend (Notre Dame's first win in the series in nine years)
The 25 October 2009 Baghdad bombings kills 155 and wounds at least 721.
MLB American League Championship: New York Yankees beat Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim, 4 games to 2
The 28 October 2009 Peshawar bombing kills 117 and wounds 213.
NASA successfully launches the Ares I-X mission, the only rocket launch for its later-cancelled Constellation program.
British Mercedes driver Jenson Button finishes 3rd in inaugural Abu Dhabi Grand Prix at Yas Marina Circuit to win his first F1 World Drivers Championship by 11 points from Sebastian Vettel
Tennis sisters Serena and Venus Williams clash in the season-ending WTA Championship decider at Doha, Qatar; Serena wins 6-2, 7-6
23rd Soul Train Music Awards: Michael Jackson, Charlie Wilson & Chaka Khan win
World Series Baseball: NY Yankees beat Philadelphia Phillies, 7-3 in Game 6 at Yankee Stadium to win Bronx Bombers' record 27th title; MVP: NY outfielder Hideki Matsui
US Army Major Nidal Malik Hasan (US Army Medical Corps) killed 13 and wounded 43 at Fort Hood, Texas in the largest mass shooting ever at a US military installation.
Breeders' Cup Horse Racing, Santa Anita Racetrack; Day 1 winners: Man of Iron, Tapitsfly, She Be Wild, Midday, Informed Decision, Life Is Sweet
Breeders' Cup Horse Racing, Santa Anita Racetrack; Day 2 winners: Pounced, California Flag, Dancing In Silks, Vale of York, Goldikova, Furthest Land, Conduit, Zenyatta
Federation Cup Women's Tennis, Reggio Calabria, Italy: Flavia Pennetta beats American Melanie Oudin 7-5, 6-2 to give the home team an unassailable 3-0 lead (ends 4-0) and their 2nd title
Joe Cada becomes the youngest champion of the World Series of Poker's main event.
43rd Country Music Association Award: Taylor Swift & Brad Paisley wins

The Netherlands officially exits the recession after experiencing 0.4% growth in the third quarter, but recovery for the Netherlands still remains fragile as the country is highly dependent on exports to maintain the recovery

Germany's growth of 0.7% in the third quarter helps lead the Eurozone out of the recession after providing overall growth of 0.4% in the same period, with the whole European Union growing 0.2%, it is reported today
The National Statistical Service of Greece states that the country has been in recession since the beginning of the year
"The Twilight Saga: New Moon", based on the book by Stephenie Meyer, directed by Chris Weitz, starring Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson, premieres in Los Angeles

The Mexican government declares its economy technically out of recession after 2.93% GDP growth in the third quarter of 2009; Mexico had been in a severe economic crisis for over a year prior to its economic rebound
36th American Music Awards: Taylor Swift & Michael Jackson win
President Hugo Chávez states that Venezuela is in recession as the economy contracted 4.5% in the third quarter
Maguindanao massacre occurs in Ampatuan, Maguindanao, Mindanao, Philippines
Susan Boyle releases her debut album “I Dreamed a Dream” (biggest selling album worldwide 2009, 2010 Billboard Album of the Year)
Fela! based on music and lyrics by Nigerian singer Fela Kuti, opens on Broadway
Flooding in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia; powerful storm brings 3 years worth of rain in 4 hours, killing over 150 people and sweeping thousands of cars away during Hajj
74th Iron Bowl: Alabama beats Auburn 26-21 in Auburn
CFL Grey Cup, McMahon Stadium, Calgary: Montreal Alouettes come from behind to beat Saskatchewan Roughriders, 28–27 on a 33-yard Damon Duval field goal as time runs out
Nikolay Davydenko of Russia wins his only ATP World Tour Finals tennis title with a 6-3, 6-4 victory over Argentine star Juan Martín del Potro in the final in London, England
Canada begins its recovery from the recession; economic growth is at 0.4% after 14 months of economic stagnation
José Mujica announced as the winner of the run-off election in Uruguay the day before and president-elect

Ballon d'Or: FC Barcelona forward Lionel Messi is named best football player in the world; wins award by a then record margin, 240 points ahead of Cristiano Ronaldo of Real Madrid with Barcelona midfielder Xavi 3rd
18th SEC Championship Game: #2 Alabama beats #1 Florida, 32-13
5th ACC Championship Game: #12 Georgia Tech beats #25 Clemson, 39-34
14th Big 12 Championship Game: #3 Texas beats #21 Nebraska, 13-12
98th Davis Cup: Spain beats Czech Republic in Barcelona (5-0)
Final Broadway performance of "A Steady Rain", starring Hugh Jackman and Daniel Craig
Bombings in Baghdad, Iraq kill 127 and injure 448.
US President Barack Obama accepts the Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo
Tiger Woods announces an indefinite leave from professional golf to focus on his marriage.
75th Heisman Trophy Award: Mark Ingram, Jr., Alabama (RB)
Boeing's new 787 Dreamliner makes its maiden flight from Seattle, Washington.
Ben Bernanke, Chair of the US Federal Reserve is named Time's Person of the Year for rescuing the global economy from the Great Recession
James Cameron's "Avatar" starring Sam Worthington, Zoe Saldana and Sigourney Weaver, released in the US, becomes highest-grossing film of all time
Former Welsh and Lions captain Gareth Thomas is the first international rugby player to reveal he is gay
US President Barack Obama receives his vaccine jab against swine flu
Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab unsuccessfully attempts a terrorist attack against the US while on board Northwest Airlines Flight 253
Chinese human rights activist Liu Xiaobo sentenced to 11 years in prison in Beijing, China for "inciting subversion of state power"
The World Health Organization says 208 countries, territories and communities have reported H1N1 cases, including at least 12,220 deaths
43 people die in a suicide bombing in Karachi, Pakistan, where Shia Muslims were observing the Day of Ashura.
Scarlett Johansson makes her debut on Broadway in the Arthur Miller play "A View from the Bridge"
